BE11:15am

The saga has reached the stage at which there is supposed to be closure of the UK-EU divorce proceedings. The drama of “no-deal” disruption was always false to the extent that more delay always was the most probable outcome, as the forex market has been indicating. Either the British Parliament supports Theresa May’s proposed divorce deal this week or it will vote for delay,
which the EU will support, with conditions attached. There seems to be no
viable third option. At this point it seems that May’s deal will fail, because
the EU has been unwilling to make any significant concession to facilitate its success.

Flaneur Cox tweet though......
Manxish Morning everyone
BE11:15am

The drama is of a different, less immediate nature. The pitiful lose-lose
Brexit negotiation exemplifies Europe capacity for political self-harm. This is the political wasteland that has led so many international investors to
conclude that both EZ and UK equity should be avoided. The only
substantial equity market in Europe to escape investor suspicion is that of
Switzerland. As a consequence, the Swiss market has become comparatively expensive.

BE11:15am

The EU is demonstrating its inability to address the problems that led to
Brexit. In particular, the structural failings of the euro system are not being
addressed. The doctrinal presumption that “ever-closer-union” is the only
ultimate solution is contradicted by the growing evidence that there is
insufficient popular support for a Political Union that would be necessary to legitimise a Fiscal Union in the euro zone. The true tragedy is that the
European project is becoming reduced to the protection of an increasingly
stagnant status quo.

BE11:21am

Sirius Minerals Plc ("Sirius" or the "Company") announces that it has received a conditional proposal from a major global financial institution (the "Financial Institution") in respect of its stage 2 financing (the "Alternative Proposal").

The Company has been pursuing a senior debt financing with a group of prospective lenders since 2016. This was most recently adjusted on 22 January 2019 to focus on a US$3 billion multi-tranche structure. The Alternative Proposal contains an alternative senior debt structure to completely replace that structure.

The Company believes that the Alternative Proposal potentially offers a more flexible and attractive solution to its stage 2 financing requirements and therefore it is pausing discussions with its existing prospective lenders to pursue the Alternative Proposal.

A number of options for the additional non-senior debt financing requirement, as previously outlined in the Company's announcement of 6 September 2018, continue to be progressed.

The Company is working towards obtaining firm commitments for the Alternative Proposal and its additional financing requirements before the end of April 2019. The Alternative Proposal is subject to the finalisation of the Financial Institution's due diligence and internal approvals.

Further announcements will be made in due course.

We think this gives some clarity around the delays in debt financing from a top-down view looks a simpler solution with only one party to deal with. Shares should react well to the news. Retain BUY.

Umtaliboy2 @IslandDweller Why limit it to the cabinet? The whole political system is a mess. A dysfunctional morass of self interested, non-listening tossers.
BE11:24am

Very intriguingly, Sirius has received a conditional Alternative Proposal (AP) from “a major global financial institution” for the company’s US$3.4-3.6bn Stage 2 financing.

Specifically, the AP comprises an alternative senior debt structure which would completely replace the three-tranche concept for raising US$3.0bn of senior debt that had been outlined by Sirius in January 2019. Encouragingly, the AP potentially offers “a more flexible and attractive solution” (according to Sirius). Consequently, Sirius is pausing discussions with existing prospective lenders to pursue the AP.

Sirius is also continuing to progress the previously outlined options for the the US$0.4-0.6bn remainder of the Stage 2 financing. The company is working to obtain firm commitments for the AP and remainder financing “before the end of April 2019”. The AP is subject to finalisation of the financial institution’s due diligence and its internal approvals.

All things considered, while Sirius is currently at development stage and still some years from becoming a cash flow-generating company, we believe that an investment in Sirius should become progressively de-risked and enjoy significant value uplift as it advances towards production.

BE11:25am

For something a little weightier, we need JP Morgan Caz. Also house broker, but aiming their SXX coverage towards a different sort of client base.

Pharma To change the subject, The Register has a story on the 737 Max aircraft. The comments are enlightening (as they often are). One theory is that a new anti-stall system might be to blame. Pilots were not told about it, and it seems to be sensitive to false inputs from one type of sensor. SouthWest updated their cockpit displays to include this sensor after the LionAir crash.I wouldn't be long Boeing (or the FAA for that matter).
BE11:26am

The announcement provides limited detail to accurately assess the financial impact of the alternative package. But at a high level, we were skeptical of SXX’s ability to complete the prior multi-tranche facility within both an acceptable timeframe and cost. Our reservations particularly centered on the $0.6-0.7bn HY portion, which we had increasingly believed might need to incorporate an equity equity-linked element. Without seeing the detail, the proposed alternative structure seemingly mitigates these risks and at the same time simplifies the structure, which on balance is positive. It also removes the reliance on the government IPA guarantee although, again without seeing the detail, it may well still involve some equity-linked element in this package (e.g. CB) which could have a dilutionary impact on current holders. We also note that prior funding targets of max 3.5x ND/EBITDA and 6-7% all-in interest costs are now likely subject to change.

BE11:27am

It's interesting that a path to avoid the government-backstopped development cash can be pitched as a positive.

1) Accounting: The factoring facility will unwind in 2019/20; US integration costs should fade in FY19e and accrued revenue –although a feature given the nature of growth and business mix –was lower in 2H; 2)Deleveraging: we saw more progress than expected in 2018(net debt was £14m lower than we expected).We expect to see a pick-up in the pace of deleveraging in 2019/20 as the factoring facility and US integration costs fully unwind.

(@Chopper: are you new here? http://goo.gl/4ojdz7 )

Barc's been in the bull camp here for a while and see the cashflow as a key positive.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

2018 results were as expected: strong 2H organic growth (c7%); overall revenue ahead; EBITDA in line,but EBITA marginally behind. Cash EPS was inline with our forecast at 17.9p. Importantly FCF was better than expected and net debt came in lower than forecast at £309.5m, representing 2.5xEBITDA. Working capital sawan inflow; the factoring facility has been halvedand accrued income, though up yoy, was down on 1H. In terms of outlook –medium term guidance is reiterated. Near term, the group expects growth in the UK in 2019 and accelerating growth in the US. We keep our organic growth forecast broadly unchanged at c3%. EBITDA is similarly unchanged, but higher D&A costs reduce EBITA by c3%. Including a higher share count we lower FY19e EPS by c5% (bringing us in line with BBG consensus) and FY20 by c3%; average EPS growth of c9%. Our FCF forecasts are broadly unchanged. EQN trades on c10.5x FY19e EV/EBITA, a discount to peers Link and Computershare (c12/13x consensus FY19e EBITA) and more in line with general outsourcing comps. On an FCF basis, however, EQN yields c9.5% in FY20e vs. peers of 6-7% and on a PE basis looks attractive on c10x FY20e PE vs. peers on c15x. We still see good upside potentialto our 300p PT, which should crystallise with consistent delivery.

Shinshin Cox has put the boot in, deal is dead, standby for a GE and Corbyn in no 10. Not sure that is fully priced in.
Phil Endless screaming feels about right.

And Liberum ......

BE11:43am

Although there are fewer positives than negatives with the FY18 results, on balance we still believe in the strength of Equiniti’s underlying business. This view is supported by the impressive organic revenue growth delivered in year (7.3%), and the 5% beat to our net debt forecasts. However, with additional costs and uncertainties being introduced with respect to the integration of WFSS, the path to a material rerating is less straight-forward than it was. The next 6-12 months will be crucial, however, should the group delivery on our updated estimates, valuation would be far too low. We therefore reiterate our BUY rating but reduce our TP to 290p (from 320p).

FY18 results a mixed bag

Underlying EBITDA was in line, although adjusted cash EPS was 8% below on a higher D&A charge and share count. Cash generation was better and debt 5% lower at £310m.

Higher D&A reduces PBT 7%

Underlying D&A expected to b c£6m higher than previously guided. This results in our FY19 PBT forecast falling 9%. A higher tax rate and share count sees EPS down 11%

Delay to WF separation

The operational separation of EQUS from Wells Fargo is now expected by June, three months later than previously guided. Total integration costs now £45m vs. £42m, and FY19 exceptionals now £5m vs £1m.

TP cut to 290p on lower est.

Reflecting the changes to our forecasts and rolling our valuation forward to FY19 sees our DCF based TP fall from 320p to 290p. 46% TSR potential implies upside to FCF already overly discounted.

BE11:50am

Such as this, from Buckingham.

PBateman Would you call the FAA independent in this?
BE11:50am

Right now, with no direct knowledge, there is a wide range of potential causes of the Ethiopian crash including: 1) pilot error; 2) a
mechanical, quality, or maintenance issue with the flight controls or engines; 3) the same MCAS/sensor issue that afflicted the Lion
Air crash, or; 4) an entirely new software problem unrelated to the MCAS issue. At this point and with no expert knowledge, we give
equal weight to all possibilities.
According to investigators, the Lion Air crash may have been caused by a faulty sensor and the data it provided to the flight control
system. Following the Lion Air crash, BA notified operators of a potential flight control problem and how pilots should deal with it if it
occurs. Specifically, investigators believe that the MCAS or Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System was fed false readings
from a sensor. In 2018, BA was considering a software upgrade to rectify possible flight control software issues. However, we don't
believe the issue has been decided and do not know if a software update has been installed.
Worst case. From an investor perspective and in our view, we think worst case would be that the Ethiopian crash was caused by a
totally new flight control system problem unrelated to the MCAS system. In that case, we think BA could need 2-4 months to develop
and qualify a temporary and/or permanent software fix and install it. If BA admitted fault, It's possible airlines could refuse delivery of
B737s until the fix is installed causing a build-up of B737s in inventory. In our view, production would likely continue as would the rate
ramp to 57/mo since BA would not likely want to disrupt the production process.

Forester @1stLtd. Me neither and I like to think of myself as DM Headline Resistant
BE11:51am

Strictly, from
a financial standpoint (and without direct knowledge of causality), we think the 2019 cash flow impact to BA is likely to be small. The
B737 is about 15% of BA's total cash flow. The initial reaction from investors could be to assume the B737 MAX 8 fleet is grounded,
that deliveries are delayed, and inventory builds until a fix can be designed an installed. Investors are likely to assume BA won't achieve
2019 expectations for $17.5B in CFO. However, assuming a software fix as we describe were to cause 2-4 months of inventory to build
up once the fleet is grounded, then we think the that BA's cash flow could be negatively impacted for 1-2 quarters by the inventory
build. However, BA is likely to make up the deliveries and cash flow by the end of the third quarter.

Pharma @Finlay, only way out of a 2 year purgatory is "no-deal". Fingers crossed (it is still the legal default).

BE11:56am

Group revenue declined -2% yoy to $529.9m (Goodbody: $537.5m) and EBITDA
came in at $107.1m, +6% yoy and in line with our forecasts. Divisionally, Casino
was +8% to $317.6m and Sports +6% to $80.3m. Bingo declined -17% to
$32.4m, Poker declined -37% to $49m and B2B fell -8% to $50.6m. A final DPS of
6c was declared (FY17: 5.9c) along with an additional one-off dividend of 2c per
share bringing the total dividend for the year to 12.2c per share (FY17: 15.5c).
The group notes that in Q1 to date, ADR is +10% versus Q418 and group trading
(adjusted for cashcade bingo) is +5% yoy (cc). The statement also notes that it’s
UK B2C business has seen continued stabilisation of revenue with Q1 B2C
revenues +10%.

BE11:59am

Valuation and investment view
Overall, FY18 was a decent bottom line outcome for 888 against a challenging backdrop. However, given the softness in B2B and Poker, we will likely reduce our top of range FY19 EBITDA forecasts downward by c.6-8%. We currently sit at $97m (before share based payments). While the downgrade is disappointing, we believe the following issues should act as supports to the share price (i) a valuation that remains attractive at 7x EV/EBITDA, (ii) it has a complete
proprietary portfolio of assets across all verticals, (iii) interesting international optionality and (iv) attractive cashflow characteristics. It remains one of the most likely candidates to take part in corporate activity.

2019 will be tough at the bottom line as a result of increased
gaming duties in the UK and investments in growth elsewhere.
However, management has shown it is willing to use the cash on
the balance sheet to advance the business strategically while
leaving a little left over for a modest special dividend.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

What might have been? What might yet be? There was an exceptional
charge to FY18 profits of US$0.9m relating to “aborted M&A efforts”. We
infer from the size, and the fact, of the separate disclosure that the deal would
have been material. In addition, 888 has put in place a US$50m RCF to
“finance its M&A activities. We believe that 888 needs a partnership of some
kind to make sense of its US strategy and we are encouraged that it appears to
have ambitions in other directions too.
888 has the geographic diversity to insulate it somewhat from challenges in
the UK. It has a technology platform, which allows it to grow revenue
efficiently in new markets and which makes it an attractive commercial or
M&A partner. With revenue back in growth in the early stages of the
current year and the prospect of a restoration of profits growth next year, we
reiterate our Buy recommendation and 220p target price.

BE12:07pm

On operations, we recently flagged in a note that the Catcher field has
outperformed and the Kraken field has underperformed. This led us to preemptively upgrade Catcher reserves and downgrade Kraken reserves by -15%. The Kraken downgrade was confirmed this morning with a 6.8MMboe (-19%) reduction due to lower-than-expected production from FPSO outages,
weather-related incidents and a higher-than-expected water cut. This resulted in an FY18 impairment of $166m, which we initially value at c15p/sh.
We note Enquest’s response to Cairn’s Kraken downgrade, maintaining the
position that it sees no reason to make any material change to Kraken reserves, citing different technical approaches to production forecasting and reserves evaluation. There are several reasons proposed for Cairn’s downgrade, the most significant for us is the occurrence of increased water cut which points to
subsurface challenges that can only increase the risk associated with the recovery of oil. Therefore, we feel Cairn is taking a more prudent approach to which we are more aligned.
